topics.body:
"@MoogSourceVermona":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b540e76368722409000c2d#post_55b540e76368722409000c2d
[bq="MoogSourceVermona"]"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b5409e6368722f21002406#post_55b5409e6368722f21002406
as much as i wish everything could go organic and free-range

it really isnt possible for us to do so right now[/bq]

Although idealistically, truly organic food would be a nice thing, that is as far as possible from the reality of it.

Perhaps you may have heard that organic foods are naturally grown, use no herbicides or pesticides, and are not genetically modified.

In practice, organic foods:
-> May be grown in greenhouses or via hydroponics
-> Are only treated with herbicides and pesticides that could arguably classified themselves as  "natural" and "organic"
-> Are selectively bred to give the biggest yields

So _realistically_ I do not see the reasoning for purchasing organic foods, although _idealistically_ this would be a great thing.

topics.body:
I thought of something interesting; you know how lately the news is constantly fucking complaining about "robots are taking our jobs"?

Automation has been going on for fucking centuries; it's just the jobs that are now being automated are jobs that previously couldn't be automated.

News is being automated so obviously that's going to piss off newscasters.  Even now a fair chunk of news stories are automatically generated from computers; hell even newscasters are starting to be automated and replaced with robots.

Basically: news, "Wait?  Computers are now taking my job?!  Kill it!  Kill it before it has a chance!"

topics.body:
"For those of you that don't know what vertical farms are":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EURY89IHOoY
Vertical farms can be organic; most of the time they're hydroponic though.  For those of you that don't know what hydroponic farms are they're even more organic than organic farms essentially because they don't have any chemicals in them or any growth enhancers.  To put it another way it's even healthier than organic farms.

topics.body:
"@liamwhite1":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b545b96368723958000bb8#post_55b545b96368723958000bb8
Ah; you know what I mean though.  Hydroponic vertical farms are healthier than anything we have on market because it can be grown in the city where people buy it, they don't need any pesticides, herbicides or fertilizers because they're in a environment where the chances of them being exposed to pests or that is marginal; also the amount of fuel to transport them is marginal compared to other forms of crop production, etc.


To put it another way the world produces enough food to feed everyone; rather the problem is the people that go hungry can't afford to eat because the amount of money to eat a sustainable diet they can't afford because most of the time the crops that are grown in their local area are outside their income level because demand is too high for them thus increasing the costs.  Hydroponic vertical farms opens up the opportunity of drastically reducing the global hunger rate because any crop could be grown anywhere in the world locally thus drastically reducing prices.


Also the drastic reduction in the destruction of woodland, the drastic reduction in carbon emission transporting food.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b5454c636872236000071e#post_55b5454c636872236000071e
Speaking of hydroponics. There is a variation where farmers with the help of symbiotic organisms, create an mini ecosystem. Called "Aquaponics":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquaponics. Such type of agriculture really isn't anything new. People in Asian countries have been growing rice and releasing fish into rice paddies for centuries.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b547406368723f990013cd#post_55b547406368723f990013cd
The thing is though that the new way of farming opens up the ability to afford food to far more people than we currently can.

To put it another way while vertical hydroponic farms won't outright end world hunger it opens up the possibility of drastically reducing the number of people that go hungry by a large portion.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

Also probably help save the delicate ecosystems and endangered wildlife in the future by preserving land.

Anyways. What do you think about "aeroponics":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeroponics?

If world hunger remains a problem. There is always the option for _synthetic foods_...
